Riding without helmet:

• Applicable law: Motor Vehicles Act (Sections relating to helmet rules).
• Typical penalty: Fine amount varies by state; commonly ₹500–₹1000 for first offence. In many states the fine is ₹1000.
• What to do if challaned: Pay the fine at the traffic police office or via e-challan portal. Keep receipt.
• Documents to carry while riding: Driving License (DL), Vehicle Registration (RC), Insurance.

Note: If the challan is wrong, note the officer details and file a complaint at the traffic police station or via the state traffic portal.

Traffic rules — quick guide:

• Obey traffic signals: Stopping at red light is mandatory. Jumping signals may attract a fine and penalty points.
• Lane discipline and speed limits: Follow posted speed limits. Speeding attracts fines and possible licence suspension.
• Parking violations: Unauthorised parking can lead to tow-away and fines.
• Fines & challans: Use your state's e-challan portal to view and pay fines online.

If fined, save challan number and payment receipt; for disputes, contact local traffic police.

Cyberbullying and online harassment:

• Relevant law: IT Act, 2000 (Sections dealing with electronic communication and cyber offences). Criminal provisions under IPC may also apply.
• Steps to take:
  1. Preserve evidence: screenshots, URLs, timestamps, messages.
  2. Report on platform: Use report/abuse option (Instagram, Facebook, Twitter) to flag the content.
  3. File complaint: For serious harassment, file an FIR at the local police station or online at the cybercrime portal (cybercrime.gov.in).
  4. Legal notice: For wrongful content, consider sending a legal notice via lawyer.

• Advice: Avoid engaging with the harasser; preserve all records and consult cybercrime cell for guidance.

How to report an online fraud / file an FIR:

1. Preserve all evidence: transaction IDs, screenshots, emails, chat logs, seller details.
2. Approach the bank/payment gateway: raise chargeback/dispute and notify bank immediately.
3. File FIR: Visit nearest police station or file online complaint at the National Cyber Crime Portal (cybercrime.gov.in). Provide all evidence.
4. Cyber Cell: The police cyber cell will investigate; obtain FIR number/acknowledgement.

Tips:
• Lodge complaint promptly. • Keep records of communications. • If large sums are involved, involve bank and cyber cell immediately.

FIR (First Information Report) — step-by-step:

1. Visit the nearest police station: Provide the details of the incident and evidence.
2. Online FIR: Many states allow online complaint registration — check state police portal.
3. Provide documents: ID proof, evidence (screenshots, transaction receipts), witness details if any.
4. Obtain a copy: The police should give an FIR copy/acknowledgement with FIR number.
5. Follow-up: Use FIR number to track investigation; contact investigating officer for updates.

If police refuse to file FIR, approach the Superintendent of Police or file a complaint with higher authorities and seek legal advice.

Common documents required when filing complaints or FIRs:

• Identity proof: Aadhar card, Passport, Voter ID, Driving License.
• Transaction records: bank statements, payment confirmations, transaction IDs.
• Electronic evidence: screenshots, chat logs, emails, URLs.
• Photographs/videos: If available, provide clear copies.

Always carry original ID when visiting police station and submit photocopies as required.

General penalties and fines (overview):

• Traffic fines: Vary by offence and state — e.g., no helmet, signal jumping, over-speeding.
• Cyber offences: Under IT Act penalties include fines and imprisonment depending on the section.
• Theft/fraud: Penal provisions under IPC for theft, cheating, and fraud with varying sentences.

For exact penalty and section references, consult a legal professional or refer to the specific statute and state notifications.

Basic legal advisory steps:

1. Preserve evidence: Save all relevant documents and digital records.
2. Do not delete messages: Maintain original copies/screenshots with timestamps.
3. File complaint or FIR: Approach police or use online portals for cybercrime.
4. Contact a lawyer: For civil remedies or legal notices, seek legal counsel.
5. Emergency: If you are in immediate danger, call local emergency services/police.

This assistant provides general guidance only and is not a substitute for professional legal advice.
